moves.5. c5 Be7: Instead of Nbd7, I have in mind to play Ne4.
moves.6. Qd3 Nbd7 7. e4: This is similar to the Marshal attack in the QGD semi-slav
moves.15. Nc4 Nd5: ha! Now my knight is perched on top of the Tree; this is how I visualize this maneuver.
moves.16. Bd2 b6 17. b4 Ba6:
!
Any Knight move and the Be2 gets its in the chin
moves.18. Rfe1 bxc5:
creating another open file.

This pays off too.
moves.19. bxc5 Rfb8 20. Rab1 Bd8 21. Na3:
??
This leads to minor piece exchanges that are better for Black and lead to a good position and a better endgame.
moves.22. Nxb1 Bxe2 23. Rxe2 Rb8:
!
With Tempo as White now has to respond to my attack, my plan, my piece.
moves.24. Re1 Bf6: I had envision Bc7 but d4-pawn is hanging.
moves.25. Be3 Rb2 26. a3 Kf8: The whole position is now what I would call "static" and every piece is in a good position so now it is time to improve your King location on the board.
moves.30... Bxe3+ 31. Rxe3 Rxb1+ 32. Kg2 Rd1 3: Even before White played Re4, I had seen that a-pawn was doomed and White can only defend by sac his d-Pawn, which would give me a 5 pawn vs 2 pawn majority in the endgame.
moves.36. Rb4: To calculate that White cannot promote that pawn, and is a fool's dream, was part of my plan and he took the bait!!
moves.45... e5:
The White King is blocked from the squares d3 & d4.

If Kd5 then the c-pawn runs to promote.
moves.49. Ke3 c3:
Same idea.
Squares d3 & d2 are blocking the King.

gameName: QGD: Semi-Slav. piece exchanges to Endgame.
